A friend of mine had a fairly mild case of covid a while back (like a year ish by now). Since then, she's developed a similar fatigue to what I've had for a few years now since catching a particularly unusual tick bite that left parts of my nervous system permanently damaged. It's been heart-rending to see her forced to essentially completely restructure her life, doubly so because I know precisely what it's like.
The idea that it might be at least partially related to easily triggered mast cells does provide some hope for us both though, as I personally developed several symptoms that closely align with post infection conditions like the aforementioned fatigue and a sudden onset of hypersensitivity, the combination of which essentially makes it impossible to do anything more intensive than making a sandwich without needing a serious break afterward. The more intensive, the longer the recovery period, making that if I have to do anything outside the house, I will have to keep the next one or two days completely clear in my schedule or I'll break down and end up disappointing someone.
I hope you'll forgive me for waiting a little while for more conclusive results to come out, though, before adding another pill to my rapidly growing pile of medication I take each day.

Just to note that for many of us with an ME/CFS or fibromyalgia diagnosis, it turns out we actually have a connective tissue disorder that’s trashed our spine, causing all sorts of downstream mechanical neurological problems.

I know of several long covid patients in the same spot.

My ME/CFS symptoms are in remission following neurosurgery, from 95% bed bound to walking and working out every day, and I’m not alone in that. Although surgery is risky, not always effective, and inaccessible to almost all candidate patients.

As far as I know this is speculative, but plenty of viruses- including covid- cause our bodies to produce various metalloproteinases which can degrade collagen, which it’s reasonable to think is more of a problem if you have a tendency to connective tissue problems anyway. It is clinically well-established that connective tissue disorder patients’ health often dramatically worsens following viral infection.

One of my family member’s ME/CFS symptoms came on after a virus. Another’s descended in multiple hits- after EBV, then mumps, then a neck injury. Mine was a series of viruses and then, bizarrely, a yoga injury to an already-weakened neck. I am the only one of any of us who has the subluxing/dislocating joints typical of connective tissue disorders, and that only came on after several years of illness. So, presuming my other family members’ symptoms also result from a connective tissue disorder, it is possible to have ME/CFS symptoms caused by mechanical issues without having the hypermobility outside the spine that more typically characterise connective tissue disorders.

I’d love to cite more papers than 10.3389/fneur.2020.00828 but ME/CFS and connective tissue disorders are woeful underfunded, let alone the intersection of the two.

Thank you for this video! I'm am so grateful for channels which help spread information and draw attention to post-viral syndromes.  Videos like this go a long way to combatting stigma by raising public awareness and validating this condition as real   To me, it is really sad that in spite of ME/CFS having had a similar disease burden to HIV/AIDs, it has been enormously underfunded and under-researched for decades (with negative attitudes and biases within Medicine).  It has long been dismissed it as mental illness, 'all in your head', malingering, or 'women's hysteria'. Interesting too that when a condition disporportionately affects women and that is poorly understood, the response is not curiosity and proper scientific inquiry, but rather a knee-jerk reaction of dismissiveness and 'it must be just anxiety or not real'.   No one took it seriously for decades, and looks like the pandemic will be the game changer because so many people are getting a taste for what this condition really feels like (including medical professionals).  Research funding has now shot through the roof.  There's a part of me that feels angry, because had it been taken seriously the way AIDS had been many decades ago, we might actually have a cure by now.  Instead, what were seeing is that COVID-19 has effectively doubled the number of people living with post-viral syndromes, and there are no adequate social resources or medical infrastructure to deal with the rising tide of disability and complex concerns that these patients have.  It's all being invented on the fly.  Right now, in my local community, there are no supports or services available for anyone dealing with a post-viral condition, yet it is widely known that this condition is so debilitating that these people do need extra help and supports with the tasks of daily living much like other disabilities.

Thank you for this video. When I was a teenager, I had a particularly nasty ear infection that caused my entire body to shut down. I had to go on multiple rounds of antibiotics and fell into a dark depression because I was basically just passing out during the middle of the day from exhaustion. Somehow despite my physical symptoms, I was told it was somehow all in my head and that I should just magically get over it. Fast forward to adulthood and college nearly killed me. I barely graduated, and when I started working I could only work a part time job and still wound up passing out dead tired after only a 4 hour shift, needing the entire rest of the day to recover. It wasn’t like I didn’t have ambitions and hobbies, but I never had any time to complete any projects I wanted to do because working took 100% of my energy. Little did I know that this wasn’t normal and that other people had an abundance of energy I could only dream of. I wasn’t lazy! My body simply wasn’t keeping up with what my mind wanted to do! I luckily had a colleague who had been experiencing similar symptoms and that’s where I first heard of Chronic Fatigue Syndrome. I unfortunately think it’s possible I got a very early case of Covid (before testing was even available) which only made my fatigue, brain fog and forgetting words even worse than they already were, and I officially caught Covid in January 2022. I’m thankful that long covid has finally shined a light on Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, but I’m also super sad that people who were suffering with these symptoms were basically being gaslight and told it was all in their head, until people who never had to experience this debilitating condition experienced it for the first time ever post Covid. I hope people take this more seriously now!

Yes, long Covid is real. I had it for 10 months after first wave infection in 2020. The virus goes away after 1-1/2 weeks, but the antibodies remains for months.

What I recommend for people who are experiencing long-covid symptoms are the following:

1. Don't despair. Never despair. The reactions of the strong symptoms can affect the psychotic part of the brain as one begins to experience hopelessness. You don't want your mind to be affected in a way that could cycle anxiety at the present time or in the future. So, stay positive and don't think that your going to die no matter how you feel. Stay focused at all times on the positive side cause the symptoms are just symptoms.

2. Do not stress the muscles by doing strong exercises because the muscle are at a state of compromise which is why fatigue, anxiety, tremors, panic attacks, etc are being experienced. Do light exercises, like short walks or light stretches and keep active so the muscles do not fall into atrophy that would worsen your symptoms. Breathing exersises are excellent but be careful with overstretching because the tearing of muscle may produce acute, terrible pain. Rest when your body "tells" you it needs it but keep it active when it can.

3. Vitamins. Vitamins are ONLY to sustain the body's health while going through the covid symptoms phase. It is not a cure of any symptoms. Some may make you feel good, MAYBE, but the goal is to sustain the body for as long as it takes to recuperate. You will be surprised at how much you could be deficient in vitamins. 50% of the world population are critically deficient in magnesium and even in Vitamin D3. Do not take multi vitamins. Some ingredients like selenium or folate may cause reactions. Keep them separate (b1, b2, d3, etc). Remember that your muscles are somehow compromised into a weakened state so a multi vitamin may cause a reaction. It's important to remain healthy so if you are not eating healthy use supplements but of low dose. For example, B12 must be no more than 2.4mcg. Besides D3 and C, Magnesium is very important because it helps the muscles to relax and is healthy for the brain. Do the research on it, I am not lying. 200mg is ok every other day until your body gets over the diarrhea. I took magnesium oxide but you should research before taking other type. Protein powder is good to give the muscles essential amino acids. Pea protein powder is good because it is the least type that has caused allergic reactions. Again, do your research according to your body.

4. Doctors are telling you that it's "all in your head"? OK, then there's nothing wrong going to a psychiatrist so that you can be prescribed Valium to alleviate anxieties , tremors, insomnia, rapid heart beats, etc. This is if you truly need it. It should be only a last resort option because some medications can help to alleviate terrible symptoms on a temporary basis. I took Valium and it did give relief. Other option may be available based on your own body's specific reaction. In 2020 I didn't have anything else that I could have explored but now they are saying over the counter Histamine products or steroids can be useful as some relief. Mount Sinia hospital in NY is now actively running a long-covid health service. Maybe in your area the same is being done? 5. DO NOT DESPAIR. This is repeated because it is impossible for me to over-emphasize how critically important it is to maintain a healthy focused mindset DURING THIS TIME. May God bless everyone during this time.

So I was diagnosed with a dysautonomic condition known as POTS just before the pandemic began a couple of years ago, and being a student in medical science, I began to learn a lot about my condition. When I recently learned that many COVID "long haulers" had symptoms of dysautonomic conditions (such as MCAS, FM, POTS) I suddenly realized that the world was about to change in so many ways because this illness now created a significant amount of people with significant disabling health issues that have gone ignored by much of society throughout human history. I grew up with my disability but it didn't become severe until I became less active in college. No amount of stairs or walking was enough activity with an autonomic condition. I had been managing the condition until this point in my life by simply attending gym classes despite the chest pain and shortness of breath.
My circulation and blood pressure were weak but none of the doctors could figure out what was happening, until 2019 when one young ER doctor who had been somewhat familiar with dysautonomia had referred me to my first neurologist which is when the diagnosis and physical therapy began (the doctor's age matters because younger doctors appear to be more familiar with recent research).

I cannot express how frustrating it can be to live with these symptoms without answers. I felt like it would eventually kill me and nobody could save me. It was horrible knowing most of my life that something was wrong with my heart, lungs, and sweat glands but I never considered that they would be neurological. Not just neurological, but that the part of the nervous system controlling every involuntary action in my body would be the source of the malfunction. Countless doctors couldn't figure it out because the symptoms were so subtle on the surface and the tests they performed came back normally because the organs are fine. It's the nerves controlling the organs and veins that are malfunctioning, hence, the dysautonomia (autonomic nervous system dysfunction).

Knowing now that so many scientists have been diligently studying these autonomic conditions as a result of the lingering "long COVID" symptoms gives me so much hope because it seems like people experiencing dysautonomic conditions won't spend a lifetime without answers. It makes me think about all of the people who've lived with this their entire lives and died without answers. How many people were disregarded as being dramatic or attention-seeking just because they experienced debilitating symptoms and suffered every time they stood up. I was told incessantly that this was "all in my head" because the research had been so new that most of the doctors I was seeing were simple unaware of autonomic conditions, let along that my issue is neurological. So COVID shone a very bright light on this new research about dysautonomia and people can finally add this to the conditions that humanity is much more aware of, which means that less people will suffer in silence without the answers and treatment that they need. It makes us much stronger as a species to understand what ailments we are facing, and Im EXTREMELY thankful that I was able to get my answers at a young age, albeit twenty years after my first experience with an autonomic dysfunction episode. I have been very fortunate to be born during an era that would eventually understand invisible illnesses, regardless of how long I'd lived in the shadows. COVID warping the entire world as significantly as it has will only benefit future generations as we learn more about these conditions and what can be done to overcome them.

I came down with Influenza A in the middle of 10th grade, and I never felt the same again. I had lots of blood tests ordered by my pediatrician in the post-infection period, as my white blood cell count had dropped below normal levels.

On top of that, I suddenly became impossible to wake up in the mornings, and would continue to feel tired throughout the day. Sometimes I would feel completely fine walking around the mall, but then I would suddenly feel this wave of exhaustion wash over me, and I had to find someplace to sit down and take a break. I would feel a bit better after some rest, but those waves of exhaustion would hit at the strangest times.

I had also developed joint pain, insomnia, stomach issues, and brain fog. On top of this, I already had a preexisting history of POTS, stomach issues, and congenital hip dysplasia that was treated successfully, but needed PT a few times over the years. Luckily, my white blood count came back up, but my other blood tests came back mostly normal, and my pediatrician was stumped, so she referred me to the local rheumatology clinic, as well as the sleep medicine clinic.

At first, I got a preliminary diagnosis of juvenile fibromyalgia, but my rheumatologist didn't see kids much, so he referred me to the only pediatric rheumatology clinic in the state, at the University hospital. She saw me, realized I was hypermobile, and sent me off to genetics, who confirmed the rheumatologist's suspicions. I actually had a genetic disorder called Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, and many of my issues could be attributed to that. My fatigue was worse than most EDS patients, but it still seemed like the likely culprit at that point, especially after my first sleep study+MSLT comes back negative.

Years later, I'm back at my old sleep center clinic. This time, I was seen by a neurologist who split his time between there and the neurology clinic nearby. Not much had changed, but I was even more tired, and had so much trouble with being exhausted in the mornings, yet struggling to fall asleep at night. Once I was asleep though, I would sleep for 10-14 hours if not woken up. Curiously, I had also started having visual hallucinations when I started to fall asleep. They were dream-like in every sense of the word, and that symptom made him suspect that something was up, along with one other nearly-forgotten fact from my medical history: these symptoms started shortly after my influenza infection.

He convinced my insurance company to pay for another sleep study, and... it came back negative. When I first heard the results over the phone, I was devastated. I almost skipped my next appointment with him, thinking it would be the same as my other negative test results. Despite my fears, I came in anyway, ready to be disappointed. Instead, he asked me "hey, question, did I forget to tell you to stop taking your antidepressant before the sleep study?"

I soon learned that both sleep studies were almost definitely false negatives due to the SSRIs and SNRIs I'd been on for years, and I actually had narcolepsy type 1. Also known as narcolepsy w/ cataplexy, research has shown that narcolepsy T1 is likely an immune-mediated post-infection disorder that's often associated with influenza (especially H1N1) and strep throat. Many doctors suspect that it's an autoimmune disorder that results in the destruction of neurons in the brain that produce an important neurotransmitter called hypocretin/orexin. The functions of this neurotransmitter are not fully understood, but we do know that not having enough of it definitely causes narcolepsy T1. Without it, the brain has a much harder time maintaining the barrier between wakefulness and sleep, and REM sleep starts to intrude into everyday life, causing excessive daytime sleepiness, sleep-related hallucinations, disrupted nighttime sleep, and cataplexy: mild-severe muscle weakness that is typically triggered by certain emotions.

Unfortunately, there aren't a lot of treatments out there for it, and nothing will make most narcoleptics feel completely "normal" again yet, but there are some good (and expensive) options out there that can really help. I'm still working on finding the right treatment for me, but unfortunately, we have learned that Adderall and Ritalin do not play well with my brain, and I'll be trying a very expensive, slightly dangerous medication called Xywav next. It definitely has some risks, as well as some weird side effects sometimes, but Xywav, and sodium oxybate in general, works really well at night to help people with narcolepsy, so it's definitely worth a shot for me.

Viele Long-COVID-Betroffene berichten von folgenden typischen Symptomen:
- psychische Belastungsprobleme wie Ängste, Depressionen, Anpassungsstörungen, Konzentrationsschwierigkeiten, sich aufdrängende belastende Gedanken und Erinnerungen, Ein- und Durchschlafstörungen
- Atemprobleme (Kurzatmigkeit) und erhöhter Puls bzw. Herzrasen
- Schmerzen, für die keine körperliche Ursache gefunden werden kann (übersensitives Schmerzgedächtnis). Hierbei handelt es sich übrigens nicht um „eingebildete“ Schmerzen, sondern um einen real gegebenen Schmerz. Das Gehirn hat nämlich einen falschen und kontraproduktiven Umgang mit Schmerzen gelernt.
- Müdigkeit und Erschöpfung (Fatigue)

Die Post-COVID-Fatigue stellt nicht nur körperlich, sondern auch psychisch eine schwere Belastung dar. Die betroffenen Menschen fühlen sich auch nach kleinen körperlichen Anstrengungen bereits sehr erschöpft und überfordert. Die Müdigkeit kann auch chronisch sein und das bisherige Leistungsniveau kann nicht mehr erreicht werden.

In diesem Beitrag gehe ich vor allem auf die psychologische Behandlung von Long-COVID ein. Es versteht sich von selbst, dass Menschen immer nach dem biopsychosozialen Modell behandelt werden sollten.
Auf medizinier Ebene braucht es medikamentöse, neurokognitive, logopädische und pulmonale Reha-Therapien, vor allem aber auch viel Zeit und Geduld auf Seiten der Patient*innen. Auch Psychopharmaka, etwa Antidepressiva gegen Depressionen und Ängste, können hilfreich sein.

Menschen, die unter Long-COVID leiden sollten sich körperlich und in der Arbeit nicht überfordern, allerdings ist auch eine Schonhaltung, sozialer Rückzug, zu viel Vorsicht und Vermeidung von Aktivitäten, die bisher dem Leben Sinn und Freude gaben, äußerst kontraproduktiv und kann Depressionen, Ängste und Schlafstörungen verschlimmern.

Folgende Verhaltensweisen können auch langfristig schädlich sein:

- weniger arbeiten oder gar nicht mehr arbeiten gehen

- weniger alltägliche Arbeiten (Haushalt, einkaufen, etwas heben oder tragen)

- weniger Tätigkeiten, die Freude machen, Spaß bereiten, Sinn geben oder als wertvoll erlebt werden

- weniger soziale Kontakte

- weniger Freundschaften und Beziehungen pflegen

- sozialer Rückzug

- vermehrter Missbrauch von Drogen, Alkohol und Medikamenten

- Vermeidung, etwas Neues im Leben auszuprobieren

- zu viele Pausen, zu viel Schlaf, zu viel ruhen und hinlegen

- mehr Medikamente einnehmen oder falsche Medikamente (etwa Benzodiazepine, welche schnell abhängig machen)

- öfters oder zu häufig zu Ärzt*innen zu gehen


Es kann aber auch falsch sein, den Körper rein funktional zu betrachten und die körperlichen Beschwerden völlig zu übergehen. Ich zwinge dann meinen geschwächten Körper, genauso leistungsfähig wie vor Long-COVID zu sein, als ob Long-COVID gar nicht gegeben wäre (Verleugnung). Auch eine Überaktivität kann schädlich sein.

Sowohl ein Übermaß an Schon- und Vermeidungsverhalten, als auch übermäßige Aktivitäten können bei Long-COVID Frustration, Erschöpfung, Depression, Ohnmacht und Hilflosigkeit verstärken.

Fragen sie sich daher, wenn sie unter den Folgen von Long-COVID leiden, welche ihrer Verhaltensweisen langfristig eher förderlich und welche eher hinderlich oder sogar selbstschädigend sind.


Viktor Frankl, der Begründer der Logotherapie, hat sehr schön formuliert, dass wir den Bedingungen unserer Existenz (etwa Körper und Psyche) nicht völlig ausgeliefert sind, sondern uns als Menschen immer bewusst entscheiden können, wie wir damit umgehen. Leide ich etwa an den Folgen einer Erkrankung wie COVID-19, so kann ich lernen, mit diesen Folgen anders und besser (personal und authentischer) zu handeln.
Eine Krankheit wie Long-COVID stellt fast immer eine massive existentielle Erschütterung im Leben eines Menschen dar. Depressionen, starke Ängste, Gefühle der Leere, innere Unruhe, Wut und Trauer können einander abwechseln.
Psychotherapie und psychologische Hilfe können Ihnen helfen, die Erkrankung in Ihr Leben zu integrieren und belastende Emotionen auszuhalten, anzunehmen und durch sie hindurchzugehen.
In dieser Erschütterung des Lebens liegen auch personale und existentielle Spuren, einen neuen Blick auf das Leben und seine sinnstiftenden Möglichkeiten zu finden. Trotz belastender Emotionen kann im therapeutischen Prozess neuer Lebensmut gefunden werden und der/die Betroffene kann sich dem Leben neu zuwenden und in Beziehung zu ihm treten.

Wichtig ist es auch, trotz und gerade wegen all Ihrer Beschwerden, dass Sie wieder den Blick auf Ihre eigenen Kraftquellen richten, um besser mit ihren Long-COVID-Beschwerden zurecht zu kommen. Viele Dinge können wir auch dann tun, wenn wir unter Beschwerden leiden.

Folgende Fragen zur Selbsterfahrung können Ihnen hier hilfreich sein:
Gibt es eine innere Stärke oder einen inneren Halt, der/die Sie schon Ihr ganzes Leben lang begleitet?

Welche Kraftquellen haben sie früher genutzt?

Welche Kraftquellen haben Ihnen in der Vergangenheit in schwierigen Zeiten geholfen, etwa in Zeiten von Krankheiten, Lebenskrisen oder wenn Sie Schmerzen hatten?

Welche dieser Kraftquellen nutzen Sie heute nicht mehr?

Welche dieser Kraftquellen könnten Sie heute wieder nutzen?

Wer könnte Ihnen dabei helfen und was brauchen Sie dafür?

Was ist heute Ihre wichtigste Stärke und Ressource?

Welche Stärken/Ressourcen und Kraftquellen nutzen Sie bereits, um mit Ihren Beschwerden besser umzugehen oder sich davon abzulenken?

Was könnten Sie trotz Ihrer Beschwerden heute noch genießen?

Was gibt Ihnen unabhängig von Ihren Beschwerden Kraft, Sinn und ist wertvoll in Ihrem Leben?

I suffered from long covid for 9 months before was able to get vaccinated. Had every symptom mentioned here + everything smelled and tasted like literal feces or mold (depending on hot/cold nature) I woke up everyday with coughs as if I was about to spit out my lungs. My friends and family would not believe me so I survived it all alone. If you're in a similar situation please be kind to yourself and know that everything will get better eventually. I mean that. I removed histamine from my diet and added niacin (vitamin B3) sources and only then I started to feel better so if you have not tried this yet I suggest you give it a shot - it changed everything for me. I'm still not 100% back yet but I feel way better. Please believe that it will all be fine. The coughs, the fatigue, the brain fog, the headaches... it will all go away eventually. We are survivors and I'm here for you all.

A-HA!!! So THIS exists but not “long” or “chronic” Lyme! We’ve been in this fight for YEARS. I was bitten by the damn tick, my dogs got sick, I got the bullseye rash but the doc said I wasn’t sick so it was ringworm. NOPE. I got sick four years later and have been sick for 20 years.

Antibiotics don’t always work, especially when it percolated all of that time. I’ve got both the arthritic and neurological. I had to go on disability when I was at the top of my game at work. But because I test positive on every single freaking Lyme test, none of them count because I don’t test positive on the ELISA, which is extremely high in false negatives and is most accurate if you do it within two days of the bite! Western blot…positive, I pee borrelia burgdorferi bacteria! So regular docs say I have “fibromyalgia.”

Lyme docs are expensive and hard to find because they lose their licenses for treating it (antibiotics).

Incidentally, dogs get the same faulty Lyme test so if your dog gets diabetes, neurological symptoms, Cushing’s out of the blue, assume it’s Lyme. My dogs both tested negative and none of these were on the dog symptom list for Lyme 20 years ago. I believe they finally added diabetes.

Atarax (hydroxyzine) and Benadryl (Diphenhydramine) are both 1st generation antihistamines that affect H1 histamine receptors.

I’ve taken loratadine ( Claritin - 2nd gen H2 receptors) and Diphenhydramine for this long term sinus post covid problem.

The Diphenhydramine seems to work best but dose is also an issue along with tiredness. The study or studies show higher dosages than normal work best but that means increased tiredness.

The normal max for Diphenhydramine is 50mg so I can’t recommend higher dosages for legal purposes but I can say the antihistamines coupled with Oxymetazoline (Afrin etc) prn and allowed me to stop coughing long enough to get some sleep because they dry you out so no mucous = no throat irritation = more sleep. I don’t recommend Oxymetazoline but it worked with this combination primarily at night.

I've had long COVID symptoms since my first COVID infection in April of 2020. I was very sick for 6 weeks and never got better. I experience fatigue, brain fog, breathing problems, and increased severity of my Bipolar disorder resulting in auditory/visual hallucinations. I've had Bipolar disorder since I was little but never hallucinated. My hallucinations started after having COVID and have only gotten worse since. Mostly feelings of being watched, voices whispering nearby, shadows walking past me, people staring at me from corners of the room, and the worst large humanoid faces with grotesque and exaggerated grins staring at me from corners, windows, mirrors, etc. I can't really be alone anymore without hallucinating, which makes work very hard. I used to be able to work 8-12 hour shifts no problem, but now have issues working even 4 or 5 hours without ending up very fatigued and sore. I've been vaccinated, which was terrible, as of last summer. Ended up getting sick and feverish for about a week. And this past October I caught COVID for a second time. Symptoms were very minimal outside of the day to day long COVID symptoms I'm experiencing. But my condition has steadily gotten worse. Even being awake at home doing nothing, I'm very tired after only 10-12 hours. Sleep isn't comfortable anymore, I constantly wake up or have night sweats. Even when I DO get comfortable I can sleep for 12-16 hours and STILL wake up tired. This has been nothing but hell, and I truly think the US did a disgusting job handling the pandemic, and its citizens an even worse job of just simply following guidelines and looking out for the neighbors.

There's always going to be folks who are just Like That or are misinformed, especially with the garbled info many people in the US, Brazil, and even the UK were received. I was still shocked by the number of people protesting masking and distancing even before we had a vaccine. It felt to me like a significant number of the able-bodied could only tolerate being inconvenienced to protect the elderly, children, and those of us with chronic conditions for about two months before they started throwing us to the wolves, er, virus, so they could get haircuts and go to bars. I guess it's just as well most of them don't know the inconvenience of juvenile rheumatoid arthritis or long covid!

My trust in the kindness of strangers has eroded a great deal over the past two years, between all the people demanding the right to be contagious, when they know Covid can kill or infect anyone with a longterm debilitating illness, and even attacking or shaming those of us daring to take precautions, both for ourselves and others, making us feel embarrassed to do so at best, threatened at worst. Nor is callousness restricted only to those misled by misinformation into believing COVID's effects are overblown or masking is useless. Lately, there's been a growing chorus of health officials, newscasters, government leaders, and even the head of the CDC saying the "good news" is that the "only" vaccinated people dying from covid now are those with existing health conditions, so let's just lift all restrictions and get back to normal!

I know she meant to say the good news was that the vaccine prevented able-bodied people from hospitalization or dying even if you had a breakthrough infection, so get it if you haven't. But what she actually said, dismissing the deaths of those with preexisting conditions, has been echoed openly or less openly by various people in authority (like TFG) since the early days of the pandemic: Oh, well, they're "unwell," so they'll die soon anyway. Grandma is happy to die for the economy. It's just poor people. It's just Them.


Think how many more people with preexisting conditions there are now than when the pandemic started. Yes, people with long covid have antibodies against COVID-19, but as new strains develop and antibody counts drop off, will that boost counteract the impact of longterm fatigue, aggravated MAST cells, scarring in lungs and/or other organs? What about everyone who gained weight or got out of shape staying home in 2020? How have stress, depression, job loss, impacted the public? How many millions of people avoided routine medical checkups or non-emergency medical procedures out of fear of catching covid, or because of an overworked health system? And how have each of those factors aggravated preexisting health conditions?

Luckily, a lot of researchers and scientists still care about the vulnerable, even if it sounds like most government officials, business leaders, the general population, and even some tactless health officials in high places want to wash their hands of the vulnerable in order to Return to Normal (tm).

They say Covid is like having the flu. It isn’t. There’s something almost indescribable about how it makes you feel when you have moderate to severe symptoms. I was never on life support, but it did get bad enough for me to have to go to the ER. There’s this film in your mouth and it takes away the taste of food, and sometimes the smell. Nothing helps. There’s little to no relief. All you can do is rest. And you feel like you never actually just get well. With the flu, you at least have a day where you wake up and you know you’re better. I still have the fog, 3 months later. I am a full-time student, work full-time, and am also a mom. Life has never been more challenging. I feel like a zombie most days. I forget what I’m doing as I’m going to do it. I cant focus on what I’m studying. I can’t even write appointments down correctly. I showed up to one appointment and the place was closed. Wrong day, wrong time and it took me a ridiculous amount of time to figure out what was going on. I have to take naps every 6 hours, so my sleep is crazy. I fall asleep at work and in class. I forget I’m cooking sometimes. I was an honor student and have been pretty successful in life, but now. I just don’t know what’s going on. I never thought it could still be Covid, but the more I read, the more I’m convinced it still has a grip on me. I want my life back!

As a woman who has struggled with an energy limiting chronic illness (ECLI) for years, it’s honestly very encouraging that the prevalence of long COVID might actually lead to more effective treatment (and less dismissiveness) for other ECLI conditions that are often just used as a “diagnosis of exclusion”. My current “diagnosis” (because it’s still unofficial) is “fibromyalgia with chronic migraines” (though using your definitions, CFS/ME would probably a better diagnosis because exercise usually makes my symptoms worse, not better), but even having that acknowledged by doctors hasn’t really resulted in better treatment, just helped me find resources on my own to help me better manage pacing and symptoms. And it’s been hard to access other types of aid, as usually doctors tell me I’m “not sick enough”, even though I can’t work a full time job because my stamina levels won’t allow for it. The stigma against ECLI conditions, and the dismissal of them as “in your head” or exaggeration, has been a challenge for me for over a decade. Very grateful for how much this video talked about things I usually have to fight to get people to even acknowledge as just statements of fact.

I got EBV (we usually call it Glandular Fever in the UK) in 2018 and ended up having to take a year off University due to having what one doctor called "Post-Viral Fatigue". A lot of the symptoms I had were similar to the ones mentioned like fatigue, brain fog etc. Especially the brain fog: any kind of over stimulation of my brain was so overwhelming I would be unable to do anything for days at a time. This would include the simplest of things like going for a walk outside with all the various sounds and lights etc. Thankfully I'm more or less better now, I still feel occasionally tired/foggy but I can deal with it a lot better now and have noticed that my diet plays a big part in these symptoms. I also found that acupuncture of all things helped alleviate my symptoms too, which would usually be the type of thing I would write off as pseudo-science nonsense, but it truly helped me recover. I also managed to go back to Uni in 2019, finish my 3rd year of my Undergraduate Degree and I've now also done a Masters and waiting to start a PhD so I truly do feel lucky compared to what so many have had to go through with Long COVID/ME. My symptoms definitely weren't as bad as others, but even still I found it extremely debilitating and was constantly worried that this was now what my life was going to be like. Its horrible that something as bad as COVID is bringing attention to these things but hopefully this can lead to a greater understanding of this as a whole and I honestly can't thank you enough also for making a video on this and bringing it to light. My personal experience was that no one, doctors included, seemed to believe me when I was describing my symptoms and its nice to have that kind of recognition, if that makes sense?

I don't think I have any lasting physical damage (at least no doctor has ever found anything), but on top of the chronic fatigue I already had, my memory and mind fog has made it impossible to hold a job let alone be a functional human being. I have to set alarms for anything important and label it because even if I set an alarm, I am likely to wake up not knowing WHY I set the alarm.

As someone who had been working the last 13 years straight doing the the same type of work (mostly food service and hospitality) I now function like someone who started a week ago. I would start forgetting what someone just said to me a few seconds ago, forgetting what I was doing while I was doing them, and forgetting the names of the people I would work with every day, go into panic attacks over every little thing all of a sudden because I KNOW that I should know all of this, but I just can't. I've even been having trouble understanding what people say. I can hear what they say, but it's like my brain can't put together the syllables into understandable words many times. Pretty much, I am a useless worker. If the place hadn't gone out of business, I would have probably left out of embarrassment anyway.

I honestly don't even know what to make of it or what to do. I've been sitting here unemployed for going on 4 months and it's no surprise that all of this has caused chronic depression and great anxiety. Not everyone who has Long Covid have M.E. (which is often triggered by a viral infection, and the main symptoms are Post Exertional Malaise, fatigue, muscle pain, brain fog among others)but a large portion probably do. I've had M.E. (please say M.E/C.F.S rather than C.F.S/M.E.) for almost 20 years, and I've been mostly housebound for the past decade, with minimum research being done (there hasn't been any research on diagnosis, treatment, etc). Post Viral Syndrome is nothing new (though based on experience, fibromyalgia is usually not caused by infection, and is slowly onsetting, unlike M.E). I'm glad those with Long Covid are getting support and money into research, but if that had been done over the past few decades that we've been begging for, perhaps there wouldn't be this explosion of Long Covid (which is mind boggling to me, as while I know research costs money, without it we have to rely on benefits to stay alive so likely costs more in the long run).

Your claim about fibromyalgia responding to exercise is not accurate. In those that do not tolerate the antidepressants that treat the majority of fibromyalgia symptoms most of them have an intolerance to exercise, but minimally incremented physical therapy, such as hydrotherapy, can sometimes improve symptoms. Any physical exertion above sedentary will make the condition worse in such people.

Also, there still is pretty much nothing known about fibromyalgia's causes or how to tailor treatment for it. We have accidently and empirically found that sleep is a factor to symptoms and that some medications improve symptoms. It is a disease that causes pain that does not respond to pain relievers fully since only the pain of spasming muscles from the illness is effected by them.

OMG, Hank/SciShow, I thought I couldn't love you more, and then you made this video.
10 years ago at the age of 8 my otherwise healthy son got a bad Norovirus infection along with a bunch of other kids and then our whole village. Everyone else recovered but a month after, my son got all the severe symptoms again, then 4 weeks later the vomiting and diarrhea were back again. This continued over a year or two until it was 6 days out of 7. He slept on the toilet for a full year and then on the floor of the bathroom for a further year. During the day he was pressured to go to school and it was hard for teachers to understand why he couldn't. He was exhausted and in pain. All regular causes were ruled out. I did research and found a disease called Eosinophilic GI Disease that fit many of his GI symptoms including choking on food and sure enough he was diagnosed with that. Meanwhile after several years of malnutrition from the constant vomiting and diarrhea he had stopped growing and a bone age scan revealed he was 2 years behind his birth age (after a new medication at age 16 he suddenly went from 5'4" to 6'1" in 18 months).
But back to his tween years, again after research I had read about MCAS causing more nocturnal symptoms so did a trial of H1 and H2 antihistamines which was successful so he was prescribed Ketotifen, a mast call stabilizer which stopped the vomiting almost overnight.

He's now 18, diagnosed with Eosinophilic Esophagitis, MCAS, POTS, IBS (C&D), migraines and many more. He's had over a dozen procedures done in the OR, had NasoGastric tubes, had several hospital stays including a month long one to try to live with the pain since they just can't treat it adequately.
He has missed so much schooling that he went from a very bright future of studying biomedical engineering to a goal of eventually finishing high school some time in the future. At 18 he has only completed 4 courses so it's going to be a long time. As if the exhaustion of the diseases and post infection syndrome wasn't bad enough he also has exhaustion and brain fog from all the meds he needs to keep him functioning (he is on over $40,000 worth of medications every year). He is currently undergoing a cardiac rehab program to try to get his fitness and tachycardia to be in a better place but it's proving exhausting too.
There has been so little hope or interest in his case, especially from the school and medical systems (some doctors would drop him because he couldn't attend appointments in person while have a severe stomach bug like symptoms).
I can only hope that the awful occurrence of Long Covid will also draw attention to cases like my son and help ensure that other kids and adults don't have to go through what he has.
He Doesnt Forget To Be Awesome though and recently won a community volunteer award in our city!

My girlfriend caught a viral infection in August 2016, was sick for a couple of weeks.
She had a relaxed September, but was still a bit tired and ill from the infection.
We started our 2nd year of university Physics in October 2016.

From day 1, she was struggling to wake up. Struggling to make the 10-minute walk to lectures. Struggling to stay awake in the lectures she did manage to attend. Struggling to stay awake when she got home. Struggling to wake up from her frequent naps for her 2 evening shifts/week in a local pub. She rapidly gained weight, and was on the brink of failing the whole year of university.

It took the better part of a year to get her a diagnosis of post-viral fatigue, and later a full diagnosis of Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS/ME). Her parents wouldn't take it seriously, just calling her 'lazy'. Her friends said the same.

She re-took that 2nd year two times (for a total of 3 attempts to pass 2nd year Physics) - every time her fatigue got the better of her and she couldn't make it through.
At the height of it, she needed 12-16 hours of sleep per day to function.

That was nearly 6 years ago. In 2022 she's still fatigued - maybe at 75% of the peak-fatigue she experienced in the past.

Things are only significantly better today because she's learned the limits of her body.
Some days she'll barely make it out of bed. Other days she might manage a 20 minute walk or a weight session at the gym.

She's barely holding down a job working 4x 8-hour days. She works, she has a 4-hour nap after work, eats dinner, talks to me for a couple of hours, goes to sleep again.
The 3-day weekend is to rest and get some chores/life things done, as well as do a little work towards finishing her degree online.

At least the fatigue/brain fog aspect of "long-COVID" seems to be very similar to what my girlfriend is living with.

I would not wish the illness on my worst enemy. It is crippling. It is drastically life-altering. It's been deeply upsetting watching her life go from a healthy and capable girl, to some who is fundamentally disabled and incapable of performing many everyday tasks.

It’s really cool seeing long covid be researched now! I got super super sick after a viral infection back in 2017 and developed POTS and Dysautonomia, and it’s interesting seeing post infection illnesses become much more prevalent after covid. Fingers crossed for a cure coming soon!

When you consider the ACE-2 receptor that Covid targets and what that receptor actually is responsible for, it isn't really surprising that an infection might have long term effects.
Even people who had minor symptoms and are fine now, there is no guarantee that it won't come back to haunt thrm later.

It's like HIV. That is bad because of what it targets. It targets your immune system and shuts it off.

No one has ever died of HIV. They die of some other infection because their immune has been compromised by HIV.

I suspect that Covid is going to be comparable. There are going to be people who caught this in their twenties that have some hidden congenital defect that would not have been an issue until their 60s or 70s. Now, with Covid, that problem will manifest in their 30s or 40s.

Society will be dealing with the repercussions of this long after the pandemic is over.

Thank you, from a person with a disability due to a chronic illness. 💖 Thank you so, SO much for your sensitive and thorough discussion here. I have Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, a genetic condition (not post-viral) that can cause a lot of these same symptoms you describe in long-haulers, ranging from fatigue to even MCAS. I feel like this video is thorough in shining light on the issues people face being taking seriously with these symptoms, the hope that current research gives for future research and treatment, and importantly, it centers the experience of those in the chronic illness and disability communities.

All I wanted to add to the discussion is this: that a lot of disabled people (like me) are worried about the world reopening right now because of the risk of becoming a long-hauler. My symptoms are already disabling - I worry about the extremely high rate of long-haulers suggested in some studies you mentioned, and how a post-viral condition on top of my genetic one might make my functionality even worse. Protecting people from post-viral infection is important, too, and I feel like a lot of discussions around re-opening aren't addressing that, and only address the risk of death due to the acute illness.

Hysteria.

Beware! The amount of people that will pop up saying what's the cause of the long covid syndrome. From vitamin D to eating garlic and oranges to rain dances....

If the scientific community isn't sure about the cause of the syndrome, saying what you think is the true cause of the condition will confuse people who might be worsening their already debilitating state.

Unless you're a doctor, immunologist, biologist or epidemiologist, posting your solutions won't help too much.

Sharing our thoughts and theories is good and stimulates our critical thinking, but be careful with the words you use.

Mast cells are also thought to play a role in interstitial cystitis.  Some people's symptoms improve with taking hydroxyzine.  Since there's only one medicine approved specifically to treat IC (Elmiron), it's very expensive ($4k per 90 day supply now and it keeps getting higher), and it's hit-or-miss if it helps people, it's good that there's something inexpensive like that for patients to try.   It doesn't help everyone either, but it's available in generic form and doesn't cost a lot.

OK i kept focus for the first half of the vid, that's all i needed to know anyway. Then it dived deep into scientific depths.

One thing I find hopeful out about this whole thing: a lot of the post covid symptoms are similar to certain neurological conditions, like Depression and Anxiety. Those same conditions have had some evidence suggesting an immune/inflammatory component. This fits with the Diphenhydramine research along with a study from Feb that showed microbiome-related risk factors for long-Covid. Covid's sudden, highly public increase in these cases may lead to more research in treatments for autoimmune/inflammation triggered neurological conditions like this.

Heck, maybe we find stuff useful for Alzheimer's or other inherently fatal conditions.

It's been 2 years since I was infected. My initial infection wasn't that bad, I experienced only mild symptoms of the flu for 3 days. Runny nose, fatigue,  sore throat, but on the second day I did experience a feeling that my lungs were filling with fluid and I was drowning. I drank juice and took antibiotics and by the 3rd day I had no more symptoms. Weeks after that infection I had trouble breathing at night, waking up with problems breathing.  I then noticed how bad my lungs were, how just walking short distances had me out of breath.  I spent all the first year working on getting back into shape. It's been 2 years now, and I can say now that I am in at least the same shape I was in as before I had the infection.  The symptoms I feel now, is uncontrollable "jerking" full body,  like a some sort of nervous system disorder, still my lungs are not completely healed, and what I would call narcolepsy (uncontrollable urges to sleep throughout the day)- this is the hardest one to deal with, especially when you are trying to have a conversation with someone and you start dozing off.

My husband (42) and my daughter (23) are both long haulers. Both have had long term issues with fatigue and cardiac problems. Tachycardia coupled with dangerously high blood pressures, with all tests coming back "normal" no matter what they looked at.

Hubby's cardiologist finally gave it a blanket DX of "pericarditis." He just finished a round of colchicine, and for the first time in two years, has not needed his nitro at all.

My daughter has a mix of respiratory and cardiology issues, brain fog, fatigue, poor blood oxygenation, increased confusion, still has unreliable sense of taste and smell. She was told she has POTS, and that it "will go away on it's own eventually." In the meantime, at age 23 she is on blood pressure meds, respiratory meds, and a neurological medication to treat greatly exacerbated tremors (she had essential tremors before Covid).

Something the damn researchers need to do is start looking to see if the virus is moving to live in the central nervous system somewhere. They really need to. I swear it's living there, because almost ALL of these symptoms are CNS based. Seems to me it would be a good idea to see if it's making a home in the body's nerves like varicella does.
